in sentencing, the sentencing seminar,

2925.text:
if you could choose, if you were a criminal
defendant and you could choose your judge

2930.text:
or you could choose your
prosecutor, which would you choose?

2935.text:
I think I would choose my prosecutor because
that's the person who is ultimately going

2939.text:
to decide what to charge, what facts to put
before the probation office and the court

2944.text:
and how hard to pursue this thing, and I
think that ultimately the sentence is going

2947.text:
to turn more on who the prosecutor is than
on who the judge it, and if that's the case,

2951.text:
then I think we need to have
much more transparency

2953.text:
about the decisions the prosecutors make
because every decision I make is on the record,

2958.text:
I have to send my sentence and my
judgment to congress basically.

2961.text:
To the sentencing commission
and then to congress.

2965.text:
I'd like tenure so that's probably okay, but
prosecutors don't have defend anything they do.

2970.text:
It's totally under the radar and you
will never know about it nor will I.

2976.text:
>> Hank Shea: Judge Sullivan,
let's keep you up here

2977.text: because you're going to get the first question.

2978.text:
>> Hank Shea: Okay, the current system mandatory
sentences punishes more harshly the low level

2984.text:
defendants because they do not have
the information the government wants

2987.text:
to get the cooperation, to get
the benefit of departure motion.

2991.text:
They can maybe get safety valve, sometimes
they can't because of their prior record.

2995.text:
Kingpins who have information can help
the government more and get the motions

3000.text:
for departure and get lower
sentences is that justice?

3003.text:
>> Judge Sullivan: Well, I would
say phrased that way perhaps not.

3006.text:
I would say that I would expand the use of
safety valves but I think the reality is

3011.text:
that kingpins shouldn't be signed up
willy nilly I mean at least in my office.

3016.text:
I mean unless you could go up the chain in a
significant way you are not getting signed up.

3020.text:
I'm troubled by offices that
sign up half their population,

3025.text:
but in terms of I guess another premise
of the question that I'm not sure I agree

3030.text: with is that this is a vertical chain.

3033.text:
I think of it as a horizontal chain and it
seems to me that a guy who is selling heroin

3037.text:
on the streets of Brooklyn or the Bronx everyday
to people like the ones who are in pictures

3042.text:
that I showed you, it requires a degree
of degradation and lack of respect

3047.text: for a human being and that is pretty bad.

3049.text:
If they are pitching every single day and they
get arrested multiple times and just return

3053.text: to it, I don't view that as a low level victim.

3056.text:
I view that as somebody who is destroying the
quality of life of people in their neighborhood.

3061.text:
People who are trying to get by
under difficult circumstances

3063.text: or trying to get their kids to school.

3064.text:
The reality is not everybody in
Hunts Point is selling drugs.

3068.text: If you say, well, what choice did they have?

3071.text:
I think you're really disrespecting the people
who are trying to make a life for themselves

3074.text: and trying to get their kids to school.

3077.text:
So, I think we have to avoid the
situations where there's gross disparities

3082.text:
where there's some guy like Marcus [inaudible]
who is doing a life sentence for what sounds

3088.text:
like very low level behavior and sounds
like he may have had real issues in terms

3092.text:
of who represented him and maybe
mental health issues as well,

3095.text:
but I don't think like Judge John
Gleason seems to that if you're selling

3099.text:
on the street then you are
by definition a nobody.

3103.text:
>> Professor Osler: Yeah, I can
respond to that very briefly.

3106.text:
In terms of seeing a moral equivalency
between the person at the top and the person

3110.text:
at the bottom, there's something there but
the problem is moral arguments don't do much

3117.text:
to markets and if you want to solve the
problem, the fact is that the person way

3121.text:
up here has skills that can't
quickly be replaced.

3125.text:
The person selling heroin on
Hunts Point we'll snatch him up

3128.text:
and there'll be someone else right
there in that place the next day

3132.text:
in many circumstances unless we have
a lot of resources poured into it.

3136.text: >> Hank Shea: Professor Osler, you're next.

3141.text:
In light of his [inaudible],
where should forgiveness

3146.text: and mercy factor into this discussion if at all?

3150.text:
>> Professor Osler: I think, you know,
when I read that in his speech yesterday,

3156.text:
I was reminded of something
that I've often thought myself,

3161.text:
which is that we hear Micah 6:8 quoted a lot,
What does the Lord, your God, ask of you?

3168.text:
Seek justice, to show mercy and
to walk humbly with your God.

3171.text:
And part of what was reflected in that
that's in what the Pope said is that mercy

3178.text: and justice are opposite poles in a way.

3181.text:
If justice is treating people the same
way and mercy is giving someone a break,

3187.text:
you can't do the same as a prosecutor or
as a policy maker, but where we have things

3194.text:
such as harsh mandatory minimums, the
mandatory guidelines in some circumstances,

3199.text:
the death penalty, juvenile life without
parole, there's no room for mercy.

3204.text:
And at the very least if we're going to follow
what the Pope is urging us towards we have

3209.text:
to most closely examine those areas
of criminal law where we offer no hope

3214.text:
and we offer no chance for mercy to
the people who are in the system.

3218.text:
>> Hank Shea: Judge, do you
want to respond to that or?

3220.text:
>> Judge Sullivan: Yeah, look
I think I sentence people.

3222.text:
I guess I'm the only one in this room who
has to look people in the eye and look

3225.text:
at their families who are often in
the courtroom and explain my sentence.

3229.text:
It's the most important thing I do and it's
hardest thing I do no question about it.

3233.text:
Not intellectually but as a matter of judgment
it goes to the heart of what a judge does.

3239.text:
And I think, I don't know a
judge who doesn't feel that way.

3243.text: I think generally as a group are pretty good

3246.text:
at seeing the humanity of
the person in front of us.

3251.text:
Congress doesn't see it,
the guidelines commission,

3254.text:
the sentencing commission
doesn't see it, we have to see it.

3257.text:
And so it's a tremendous
responsibility and it weighs on you.

3261.text:
At the same time I often think if
I, if I give this person a break

3266.text:
and they recidivate, it's
not going to affect me.

3268.text:
They're not coming to my neighborhood to
sell drugs or to engage in pushing robberies

3272.text:
because pushing robbers are
also asking for mercy.

3275.text:
The consequences will by bore
and felt by somebody else.

3278.text:
This person recidivates and kills someone I
think that person's family might be justified

3284.text: in saying what were you thinking?

3286.text:
So I work very hard in my sentencings
to make sure that I remind the defendant

3291.text:
that they matter, that they are precious,
that I've thought about them and I've thought

3296.text: about what this is going to do to their family.

3298.text:
And I think sometimes just doing that goes a
long way to showing that they are important

3304.text:
and most sentences I'm imposing are not life
sentences they're a few years, which are real.

3309.text:
I wouldn't want to be doing a few years,
but at the same time they will get out,

3313.text:
they will be young, they will have a life
and my hope is that showing them respect

3318.text:
and treating them with dignity will have an
impact on them and so I hope that's true,

3323.text: but I don't have the data that can back that up.

3326.text:
But in terms of just saying, all
right, I'm giving you less time

3328.text:
because I'm feeling merciful today I'm
not sure what is to guide that, you know,

3333.text:
because I think the person shows great
sorrow that I think is important but I have

3339.text:
to ultimately judge whether I think
they're going to do it again also.

3343.text:
>> Hank Shea: Is that the last word
or we have time for one more question?

3345.text:
>> Hank Shea: Okay, one more question and,
Judge, let's take advantage of you being here.

3350.text:
You were a prosecutor early in your
career and you had to have drug cases

3353.text:
that weren't the kingpins that
involved the street dealers.

3357.text:
As you sit in judgment now, do you think back
to any of those cases about the sentences

3362.text:
that were imposed and wonder whether they should
have an impact on your sentencing as a judge?

3368.text:
>> Judge Sullivan: Well, look, every
sentencing I do now I am a product

3373.text: of the sentences I've done, I am a product

3375.text:
of the cases I have prosecuted
no question about that.

3378.text:
You try to be consistent and you try to make
sure that what you're doing now is consistent

3382.text:
with what you've done before unless what
you think you did before was really wrong.

3385.text:
Now, I have the advantage I think of being
in a district where we were bringing,

3390.text: my threshold was 5 kilos of cocaine.

3393.text: I didn't take cases lower than that.

3395.text:
And so that meant that the other cases, those
smaller cases generally went to the state.

3400.text: I wasn't there for federal day.

3402.text:
So I think that I saw this very
differently than Professor Osler did,

3406.text:
but I think prosecutors have to have discretion,
and I think they have to be able once

3410.text:
in a while say we shouldn't prosecute
this to the full extent of the law.

3414.text:
>> Hank Shea: Mark, 30 seconds
for the last word.

3419.text:
First of all you know if you ask me the
same question what cases do I remember?

3425.text:
There are some cases I remember
that I wish I could do over again

3428.text:
that I could have mitigated
the sentence somehow.

3431.text:
There's others where I wish I had taken the
dangerousness of the person more seriously

3435.text:
and thought, had data on recidivism which
we still don't have enough to look at,

3441.text:
but finally I think the most important thing
that's been said this whole segment is what

3448.text:
Judge Sullivan just said about being a judge,
in that sense of looking someone in the eye

3452.text:
and the moral commitment that comes with
having to decide their fate and that he takes

3458.text:
that seriously and has the risk, the
emotional risk that comes with that.

3469.text:
That that is part of our system and we're very
lucky to have it and perhaps what I'm asking

3475.text:
for more than anything is that we have
the law allow for more of that for people

3480.text:
of strong hearts and minds who have
the experience of Judge Sullivan

3484.text: to make the decision in these cases.

3486.text:
>> Judge Sullivan: I think we have
moved in that direction candidly.

3489.text:
I mean I think when we were doing this as
prosecutors, it was a pretty bloodless affair.

3494.text: Nobody showed up there was no reason to.

3496.text:
Now families come, they write me letters,
the sentencing submissions are twice as thick

3500.text: as they were when I was a prosecutor.

3502.text:
I think that shows that we're
allowing people to exercise discretion.

3506.text: I think that's as good thing.

3508.text: Can I say one other thing before we sit down?

3510.text:
When Mark Osler and I were classmates at
Yale, he had spent some time the year before

3516.text:
in Botswana, and I have never forgot this
he told me, he shared with me a year book

3521.text:
of a school in Botswana and this was
something that was written by a student

3525.text: at Saint Joseph's School in Kgale, Botswana.

3529.text: It struck with me for 25 years now.

3532.text: This is what it says, oh, how wonderful you are.

3535.text: You are famous throughout the country.

3537.text: All people speak about you oh wonderful school.

3540.text:
How quick and nice you developed
with all beautiful buildings

3543.text:
around with all the kindest teachers
and students, oh, wonderful school.

3547.text:
From you we get the best education,
from you we learn good manners,

3551.text:
from you we become good citizens,
oh wonderful school.

3554.text:
A place where peace is maintained,
a place where prayers are said.

3558.text:
How I wish never to leave this
place, oh, wonderful school.

3562.text:
Now this was a kid, a high school
kid, but I've often thought

3564.text:
to myself I mean this Saint Thomas Law
School is, I mean I'm sure much richer

3570.text:
than that school, but I hope that each of
you feels that sense of wonder and excitement

3575.text:
at your school and you must
because it's a Friday

3577.text:
and I see you folks here today thoroughly
engaged, but this is a special place

3582.text: because of professors like this one and others.

3585.text:
And so I think you are very lucky and I hope
that you will always hold this place close

3589.text:
to your heart because this is a
rarity and it is a very special place.

3592.text: So I'm very delighted to be here.
